title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim about the area of the intertidal zone a species of intertidal plant that has thick, shiny leaves that reflect sunlight is best adapted to live in, such as any of the following:

· The organism would likely live in the high tide area where it is exposed to more sunlight. The shiny coat would reflect some light.

· The organism would likely live in the high tide area where it is exposed to longer periods of dryness. The thick leaves would prevent desiccation.

The response makes a claim about the area of the intertidal zone a species of intertidal plant that has thick, shiny leaves that reflect sunlight is best adapted to live in, such as one of the following:

· The organism would likely live in the high tide area where it is exposed to more sunlight. The shiny coat would reflect some light.

· The organism would likely live in the high tide area where it is exposed to longer periods of dryness. The thick leaves would prevent desiccation.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe a government action a conservation group could advocate for that would improve a specific marine provisioning ecosystem service, such as any of the following:

· Impose catch limits to protect the fish/seafood stocks

· Restrict access to certain marine areas to help bring back fish/seafood stocks

· Enact policies to reduce pollution that enters waterways to protect fish/seafood stocks

· Impose restrictions on the use of mangroves for timber/fuel

· Impose restrictions on the extraction of certain marine resources to protect stocks of marine materials used in commercial applications (minerals, pharmaceuticals, health/beauty products)

· Educate the public/make public service announcements regarding the importance of marine provisioning ecosystem services to protect food/water/fuel/etc

The response describes a government action a conservation group could advocate for that would improve a specific marine provisioning ecosystem service, such as one of the following:

· Impose catch limits to protect the fish/seafood stocks

· Restrict access to certain marine areas to help bring back fish/seafood stocks

· Enact policies to reduce pollution that enters waterways to protect fish/seafood stocks

· Impose restrictions on the use of mangroves for timber/fuel

· Impose restrictions on the extraction of certain marine resources to protect stocks of marine materials used in commercial applications (minerals, pharmaceuticals, health/beauty products)

· Educate the public/make public service announcements regarding the importance of marine provisioning ecosystem services to protect food/water/fuel/etc

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify and describe electricity generation by harnessing ocean cycles, such as any of the following:

· Tidal energy/tidal power (tidal barrage, tidal turbine, tidal fence) converts the energy from tides into electricity. The turbine is connected to a generator that converts the movement of water from the tides into electricity.

· Ocean thermal energy conversion ( OTEC MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=xfr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaGaae4taiaabsfacaqGfbGaae4qaaaa@392B@ ) uses the temperature difference between the hot surface waters of the ocean and the cold deep-sea water to turn a turbine generator to create electricity.

The response identifies and describes electricity generation by harnessing ocean cycles, such as one of the following:

· Tidal energy/tidal power (tidal barrage, tidal turbine, tidal fence) converts the energy from tides into electricity. The turbine is connected to a generator that converts the movement of water from the tides into electricity.

· Ocean thermal energy conversion ( OTEC MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=xfr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaGaae4taiaabsfacaqGfbGaae4qaaaa@392B@ ) uses the temperature difference between the hot surface waters of the ocean and the cold deep-sea water to turn a turbine generator to create electricity.

title: Part J
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify the best roof color for a building located around 23 degrees latitude in the Southern Hemisphere and does not explain why the identified roof color should be used in the building design, such as the following:

· A light or white roof would reflect more solar radiation (or absorb less heat), keeping the building cooler.
